title: 111_hr3632
content: The Federal Judiciary Administrative Improvements Act of 2009 includes amendments to the title and governance of senior judges in the United States Code. The Act also revises the statutory description of the District of North Dakota. The Federal Judiciary Administrative Improvements Act of 2009 amends Section 114 of title 28, United States Code, to designate North Dakota as one judicial district with court locations in Bismarck, Fargo, Grand Forks, and Minot. The amendment does not affect pending cases or the composition of juries in the District of North Dakota. The section and its amendment will take effect 90 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Disability retirement and cost-of-living adjustments for territorial judges will be implemented 90 days after the Act's enactment. Section 373 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to specify the compensation and allowances for senior judges performing judicial duties. Additionally, judges of certain district courts who are not reappointed are entitled to benefits upon reaching the age of 65 or relinquishing office. Upon reaching 15 years of judicial service, a judge is entitled to an annuity equal to their last salary. For service less than 15 years, the annuity is proportional. Judges with at least 5 years of service who retire due to disability receive benefits for life. The amendment allows retired judges to receive an annuity equal to 40 percent of their last salary or a proportional amount based on years of service. A cost-of-living adjustment is provided, but the total annuity cannot exceed the salary of an active judge. The amendment applies to recalled judges' compensation, judges not reappointed, and cost-of-living increases for retiring judges before, on, or after the enactment of the Act. Annual leave limit for judicial branch executives. The amendment to Section 6304(f)(1) of title 5, United States Code adds a provision for senior executive positions in the judicial branch. The amendments will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. FEDERAL JUDICIAL CENTER PERSONNEL MATTERS. The amendment to Section 625 of title 28, United States Code, allows the Director to appoint additional professional personnel as needed, with compensation limitations based on Executive Schedule pay rates. The salary of reemployed annuitants under specific chapters of title 5 will be adjusted accordingly. Amendments to subsections (c) and (d) involve removing specific references and updating General Schedule pay rates. These changes will take effect upon the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7 amends Section 3553(c)(2) of title 18, United States Code, replacing "the written order of judgment and commitment" with "a statement of reasons form issued under section 994(w)(1)(B) of title 28." The amendment will take effect upon the enactment of this Act. SEC. 8 addresses pretrial services functions for juveniles. SEC. 8 amends Section 3154 of title 18, United States Code, to include pretrial services functions for juveniles awaiting adjudication, trial, or disposition under chapter 403 of this title who are not detained. The effective date of these amendments is upon the enactment of this Act. SEC. 9 amends Section 2519 of title 18, United States Code, changing the reporting schedule for criminal wiretap orders. The amendments specify new deadlines for judges to report on orders issued or denied for interceptions. The effective date of these changes is upon the enactment of this Act. SEC. 10 sets thresholds for administrative review of non-attorney case compensation. SEC. 10 amends Section 3006A of title 18, United States Code by adjusting dollar amounts for certain provisions. The amendment adjusts dollar amounts for certain provisions under Section 3006A of title 18, United States Code. The adjustments take effect on the same day as corresponding adjustments under section 5303 of title 5. The effective date for the amendments is the date of the enactment of the Act. The amendment under section 5303 of title 5, United States Code, takes effect after the enactment of this Act. The House of Representatives passed the bill on October 28, 2009.
